Question: A researcher wants to test whether a new fertilizer (Fertilizer X) increases tomato plant growth compared to a standard fertilizer.
The researcher has 100 tomato seedlings of the same variety available for the experiment.
Design a simple experiment to test the effectiveness of Fertilizer X, and identify one potential confounding variable that should be controlled.

What would be the independent and dependent variables in this experiment, and what would constitute an appropriate control group? 

 Solution: 
<think>
Alright, so the researcher wants to test whether this new fertilizer, Fertilizer X, actually increases tomato plant growth compared to the standard fertilizer.
They have 100 tomato seedlings available, which is a good number to work with.
First, I need to think about how to set up the experiment.
Since the main question is whether Fertilizer X is more effective than the standard, it makes sense to compare the two under similar conditions.
That way, any differences in growth can be attributed to the fertilizer, not to other factors.
So, the independent variable here is the type of fertilizer.
Each seedling will either get Fertilizer X or the standard fertilizer.
The dependent variable is the growth of the tomato plants.
I'll measure this by things like height, number of leaves, and maybe yield at harvest time.
Now, to avoid any confounding variables, I need to control for other factors that could affect growth.
One big one is the amount of sunlight each plant gets.
If some plants get more sun than others, that could skew the results.
To handle this, I'll make sure all the seedlings are planted in the same area with the same exposure to sunlight.
Another thing is water availability.
Even if the fertilizers are the only difference, plants need consistent water to grow well.
So, I'll water all the seedlings equally, maybe using a watering schedule to ensure consistency.
Temperature could also play a role.
If some plants are in different parts of a greenhouse or outdoors, they might experience varying temperatures.
To mitigate this, I'll keep all plants in the same environment, whether that's a controlled greenhouse or a uniform outdoor area.
As for the control group, it should receive the standard fertilizer to compare against Fertilizer X.
The control group will have the same conditions as the treatment group—same sunlight, water, temperature—so any differences in growth can't be due to those factors.
Putting it all together, I'll divide the 100 seedlings into two groups of 50.
One group gets Fertilizer X, and the other gets the standard.
I'll monitor all plants equally for any variables that could affect growth and measure their growth at the end of the experiment.
I think that covers the setup.
Now, onto the variables: independent is fertilizer type, dependent is growth.
The control group is the standard fertilizer group, and the confounding variable is sunlight, which I can control by placing all plants in the same area.

</think>

**Final Answer:**

**Independent Variable:** Type of fertilizer (Fertilizer X vs.

Standard Fertilizer)

**Dependent Variable:** Growth of tomato plants (measured by height, number of leaves, and yield)

**Control Group:** Seedlings treated with the standard fertilizer

**Confounding Variable:** Sunlight exposure (all plants should be exposed to the same amount of sunlight)

**Design:** Divide 100 tomato seedlings into two groups of 50.
One group will receive Fertilizer X, and the other will receive the standard fertilizer.
Ensure all plants are grown under identical conditions (same soil, water, temperature, and sunlight).
Measure growth at the end of the growing season.
